pullRequest.body:
Extend `RingTheory.Flat.iff_rTensor_injective` to all ideals

Using an elementary argument after Dummit and Foote (2004, Ex. 10.25)

---
[Zulip thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/116395-maths/topic/flat.20modules/near/402873609)

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
I had fun naming `exists_fg_le_eq_rTensor_subtype_codRestrict` (there `exists` a `f`initely `g`enerated ideal J `â‰¤` I such that x `= rTensor `J.`subtype.codRestrict` I ..), but more sensible suggestions would be appreciated.

[Edit] I noticed `Submodule.inclusion` exists, so now it's called `exists_fg_le_eq_rTensor_inclusion`.
Force push (sorry) - fix my email address in the reviewdog commit

A couple of things occur to me.
* If `exists_fg_le_eq_rTensor_inclusion` is generally useful, then so might be its flipped version with `lTensor` and their corollary for the tensor product of two submodules
* Splitting the following lemma out of `iff_rTensor_injective'` might be convenient for users:
```lean
theorem rTensor_subtype_injective_of_forall_fg :
    (âˆ€ â¦ƒI : Submodule R Nâ¦„ (_ : I.FG), Function.Injective (LinearMap.rTensor M I.subtype)) â†’
      âˆ€ I : Submodule R N, Function.Injective (LinearMap.rTensor M I.subtype) := sorry
```
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by alreadydone.

> A couple of things occur to me. ....

I think the lemmas are pretty technical and not of obvious general interest, so I suggest we just let people extract proofs and add variants when they actually need them.

:v: bustercopley can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

I agree you can remove the parenthesis as suggested by Junyan. Thanks!

bors d+

I agree you can remove the parenthesis as suggested by Junyan. Thanks!

bors d+

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion Â· exact fg_span_singleton i.val Â· rewrite [span_le, Set.singleton_subset_iff]; exact Subtype.mem i ```

slightly golfed: removing some redundant parentheses, and use `obtain rfl`, `rTensor_comp_apply`. `rw` is much more idiomatic in mathlib than `rewrite`, in fact I don't recall ever seeing the latter in my life!
```suggestion
    Flat R M â†” âˆ€ I : Ideal R, Injective (rTensor M I.subtype) := by
  rw [Flat.iff_rTensor_injective]
  refine âŸ¨fun h I => ?_, fun h I _ => h IâŸ©
  letI : AddCommGroup (I âŠ—[R] M) := inferInstance -- Type class reminder
  rw [injective_iff_map_eq_zero]
  intro x hxâ‚€
  obtain âŸ¨J, hfg, hle, y, rflâŸ© := exists_fg_le_eq_rTensor_inclusion x
  rw [â† rTensor_comp_apply] at hxâ‚€
  letI : AddCommGroup (J âŠ—[R] M) := inferInstance -- Type class reminder
  rw [(injective_iff_map_eq_zero _).mp (h hfg) y hxâ‚€, _root_.map_zero]
```

Thanks!

`rewrite` and `rw` are not the same thing (see the `rw` docstring). I prefer to use the one I mean in each case. It's [not a popular position](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/270676-lean4/topic/tactic.20docstrings/near/393803105), but it's correct, and I don't want to do it the wrong way just because everyone else does. Not a hill I'll choose to die on, ultimately, but do you mind if apply the rest of the suggestion but change the non-finishing `rw`'s back to `rewrite`s?

> do you mind if apply the rest of the suggestion but change the non-finishing `rw`'s back to `rewrite`s?

Done. Let me know if you feel strongly about `rw` vs `rewrite`.
Sounds good!

might remove some parentheses here if you want
```suggestion
    Flat R M â†” âˆ€ â¦ƒI : Ideal Râ¦„, I.FG â†’ Injective (rTensor M I.subtype) := by
  have aux : âˆ€ I : Ideal R, (TensorProduct.lid R M).comp (rTensor M I.subtype) =
```
(there's one more below after the =)
Ah, this part is not my code. See #7567. I should probably not touch it. I'll undo this.
Reverted.

I think you need not abstain from touching existing code as long as you see an improvement, but LGTM

maintainer merge

similarly here
```suggestion
      âˆƒ J : Submodule R N, J.FG âˆ§ âˆƒ (hle : J â‰¤ I) (y : J âŠ— M),
        x = rTensor M (J.inclusion hle) y := by
  induction x using TensorProduct.induction_on with
  | zero => exact âŸ¨âŠ¥, fg_bot, zero_le _, 0, rflâŸ©
  | tmul i m => exact âŸ¨R âˆ™ i.val, fg_span_singleton i.val,
      (span_singleton_le_iff_mem _ _).mpr i.prop,
      âŸ¨i.val, mem_span_singleton_self _âŸ© âŠ—â‚œ[R] m, rflâŸ©
  | add xâ‚ xâ‚‚ ihxâ‚ ihxâ‚‚ =>
    obtain âŸ¨Jâ‚, hfgâ‚, hleâ‚, yâ‚, rflâŸ© := ihxâ‚
    obtain âŸ¨Jâ‚‚, hfgâ‚‚, hleâ‚‚, yâ‚‚, rflâŸ© := ihxâ‚‚
    refine âŸ¨Jâ‚ âŠ” Jâ‚‚, hfgâ‚.sup hfgâ‚‚, sup_le hleâ‚ hleâ‚‚,
      rTensor M (Jâ‚.inclusion (le_sup_left : Jâ‚ â‰¤ Jâ‚ âŠ” Jâ‚‚)) yâ‚ +
        rTensor M (Jâ‚‚.inclusion (le_sup_right : Jâ‚‚ â‰¤ Jâ‚ âŠ” Jâ‚‚)) yâ‚‚, ?_âŸ©
    simp_rw [map_add, â† rTensor_comp_apply]
    rfl
```

Great! I somewhat prefer the original statement with the four hypotheses in the existential. That style seems not uncommon. Slightly more strongly I prefer not to use `simp_rw` when `rewrite` suffices, since `rewrite` (or `rw`) is a lot faster. I like the `obtain` and `rTensor_comp_apply`.

I also like the replacement of `refine` by `exact`, but `Subtype.prop` is a rather subtle theorem, and I prefer the simple accessor `Subtype.property` when the subtlety is not needed. It's easier to understand what the code is doing.
Applied with some modifications.

`Subtype.property` is syntactically `p x.val` while [Subtype.prop](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Subtype.html#Subtype.prop) is `p â†‘x`. They used to be different in Lean 3 but are practically the same in Lean 4 due to how coercion now works. Therefore I think you can think of `Subtype.prop` as a shorthand for `Subtype.property`. (Actually I think `x.2` is also common in mathlib (`.2` for `Iff.mpr` is also common).

```suggestion
/-- Every `x : I âŠ— M` is the image of some `y : J âŠ— M`, where `J â‰¤ I` is finitely generated,
```
